Introduction

Breast pain, or mastalgia, is a common issue affecting up to 70% of women at some point in their lives.  Although often benign, breast pain can cause significant distress and, in some cases, may indicate an underlying pathology.  A systematic approach to history-taking, clinical examination, and diagnostic evaluation differentiates benign from malignant causes and guides management.



Breast pain is broadly classified into:



  • Cyclic breast pain:  The most common type of breast pain.  Pain originates in the breast and varies throughout the menstrual cycle.
  • Noncyclic breast pain:  Pain originates in the breast but does not have a temporal correlation to the menstrual cycle.
  • Extramammary (referred) pain:  Pain originates outside the breast but is perceived as breast pain.

Pathogenesis



The underlying mechanisms of breast pain vary depending on the etiology.

Cyclic breast pain



Cyclic breast pain is due to hormonal fluctuations that occur with the menstrual cycle (

figure 1
).  The late luteal phase is associated with a rise in progesterone (stimulates breast stromal tissue) and estrogen (stimulates glandular elements in the breast (
figure 2
)).  These hormonal changes lead to ductal and stromal proliferation, fluid retention, and breast tenderness in the days immediately prior to the onset of menstruation.

Noncyclic breast pain



Noncyclic breast pain is usually due to local factors in the breast, including inflammation, tissue trauma, fluid retention, noncyclic hormonal conditions, structural lesions, and mechanical stress.  Various etiologies include:



  • Hormonal conditions:  Pregnancy, hormone replacement therapy, hormonal contraceptives.
  • Benign lesions of the breast:  Mammary duct ectasia, fibroadenoma, breast cysts.
  • Malignant lesions of the breast:  Invasive ductal carcinoma, invasive lobular carcinoma, inflammatory breast cancer (
    figure 3
    ), Paget disease of the breast (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Mechanical stress or trauma:  Stretching of Cooper (suspensory) ligaments (particularly with large breasts) (
    figure 5
    ), fat necrosis, pain related to surgery or injuries.
  • Breast pain related to lactation:  Breast engorgement, candidal infection, galactocele, mastitis (
    figure 6
    ), breast abscess (
    figure 7
    ).

Extramammary pain



Extramammary pain is due to pathology affecting various nearby organs that can be perceived as pain in the breast.  Possible etiologies include:



  • Chest wall:  Overuse, injury, or inflammation of pectoralis major and minor muscles; costochondritis; chest wall irritation (eg, herpes zoster, postherpetic neuralgia) or trauma.
  • Neurologic:  Irritation of the intercostal nerve (which innervates the breasts), cervical radiculopathy.
  • Lung:  Respiratory infection, pulmonary embolism.
  • Cardiac: Ischemic heart disease (particularly left-sided breast pain), pericarditis.
  • Gastrointestinal tract:  Gastroesophageal reflux, gallbladder disease.

Clinical presentation

Cyclic breast pain



Cyclic breast pain usually causes bilateral, diffuse breast pain that may be worse in the upper outer quadrants.  Onset occurs monthly in the week immediately prior to menses, and pain usually resolves with menstruation.  It may be accompanied by other symptoms of the late luteal phase, such as bloating, fatigue, irritability, and mood swings.

Noncyclic breast pain



Noncyclic breast pain can be sharp, burning, or aching.  It may affect one or both breasts and can be diffuse or focal.  The pain may be constant or intermittent, but it does not correlate with the menstrual cycle.  Depending on the etiology, patients may report additional symptoms such as a breast mass, nipple discharge, or changes to the appearance of the breast.

Extramammary pain



Extramammary pain is more likely to be unilateral than bilateral, and the pain can be dull or sharp and intermittent or constant.  Pain that is due to nerve irritation or injury is frequently burning in quality.  Depending on the etiology, pain is often worse during certain activities (eg, eating, deep breathing, movement, exertion) and is frequently accompanied by pain in other locations (eg, sternum, abdomen, back, neck).

Clinical assessment



A thorough history should be obtained, including:



  • Characteristics of breast pain:  Location, quality, duration, relation to menstrual cycle, precipitating or exacerbating factors.
  • Associated symptoms:  Breast mass, nipple discharge, fever, pain in other locations.
  • History of breast or chest wall trauma or surgery.
  • Gynecologic and obstetric history:  Menstrual cycle, pregnancy, lactation.
  • Medication use.
  • Family history of malignancy.


A physical examination should also be performed:



  • Cardiac, respiratory, and abdominal examination may reveal signs of extramammary causes of breast pain, including:
    • Herpes zoster:  Dermatomal rash.
    • Costochondritis:  Tenderness to palpation of costochondral junctions.
    • Pericarditis:  Pericardial friction rub on auscultation.
    • Respiratory infection:  Rales, rhonchi, egophony, dullness to percussion.
    • Muscular chest wall pain:  Reproducible pain with activation or palpation of the involved muscle.
  • Breast examination (inspection and palpation) is used to evaluate for:
    • Breast symmetry.
    • Signs of infection:  Erythema, induration, and warmth.
    • Potential signs of malignancy:  Nipple retraction, peau d'orange (thickened skin with dimpling, resembling the skin of an orange), ulceration, bloody nipple discharge, and axillary lymphadenopathy.
    • Palpation for breast masses, tenderness, or fluctuance and localized tenderness.

Evaluation

Cyclic breast pain



No further evaluation is necessary when the clinical assessment is consistent with cyclic breast pain and there are no abnormal findings on physical examination.  Depending on patient age, risk factors for malignancy, and preferences, breast imaging can be considered for further reassurance.

Noncyclic breast pain



Laboratory evaluation is not typically required for most cases of mastalgia; however, β-hCG testing may be considered to rule out breast pain related to pregnancy, and TSH and prolactin levels should be obtained in patients with galactorrhea (bilateral milky nipple discharge).  Except for breast pain that is clearly due to pregnancy or complications of lactation, breast imaging (mammography or ultrasonography) is indicated for patients with noncyclical, unilateral, or focal breast pain or in any patient with concerning findings on breast examination.  The choice of imaging depends on patient age:



  • Age <30:  Breast ultrasonography is usually used for first-line assessment because younger patients tend to have higher breast density (limiting visualization of some masses on mammography) and lower risk for malignancy.
  • Age 30-40:  Either mammography or breast ultrasonography may be a first-line modality, depending on patient factors and suspected diagnosis.  Often, both are performed because the studies are complementary.
  • Age ≥40:  Mammography is performed first, but ultrasonography is often performed for further evaluation.


When imaging findings are equivocal or concerning for possible malignancy, core needle biopsy is performed to establish a histologic diagnosis (

figure 8
).

Extramammary pain



Further evaluation may include chest or abdominal imaging and ECG, as well as other tests, as directed by the suspected etiology.

Management

Cyclic breast pain



First-line management is reassurance and lifestyle modifications, including wearing well-fitted, supportive bras.  Using evening primrose oil and limiting caffeine intake may have some benefit.



Pain management typically begins with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (oral or topical).  Second-line medications may be indicated when significant pain persists despite several months of treatment with first-line medications, but use is limited by adverse effects.  These include:



  • Danazol:  A synthetic androgen.  Adverse effects include hirsutism, acne, breast atrophy, menstrual irregularities, and hot flashes.
  • Tamoxifen:  A selective estrogen receptor modulator.  Adverse effects include hot flashes and menstrual irregularities, as well as increased risk for venous thromboembolism, stroke, and endometrial cancer.


In some patients, symptoms of cyclic breast pain may improve with oral contraceptive pills due to manipulation of the menstrual cycle (and decreased hormonal fluctuations).  Most cases of cyclic breast pain respond to conservative management and analgesics, and the symptoms often spontaneously resolve after several months.  The symptoms may wax and wane over the reproductive years and tend to resolve with menopause.

Noncyclic breast pain



The same conservative measures and pain management options used for cyclic breast pain may help with noncyclic breast pain.  Additional interventions depend on the etiology:



  • Hormonal conditions:  Consider stopping or adjusting the dose or formulation of hormonal medications (oral contraceptive pills, hormone replacement therapy) that may be contributing to pain.
  • Benign breast lesions:  Many benign lesions can be managed with observation.  Surgical excision can be performed for symptomatic masses such as fibroadenomas.  Cysts can be drained through fine-needle aspiration (
    figure 9
    ).
  • Malignant breast lesions:  Treatment may involve surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and hormonal therapy, depending on stage and tumor characteristics.
  • Breast infections:  Mastitis is treated with antibiotics, and abscesses typically require aspiration or incision and drainage.
  • Lactation-related pain:  Pain may improve with proper breastfeeding technique and interventions such as the use of nipple shields and gentle massage to promote opening of clogged ducts.


The prognosis is excellent for benign, treatable etiologies of noncyclic breast pain (eg, mastitis, breast cyst, fibroadenoma).  Noncyclic breast pain not found to have a specific etiology frequently resolves spontaneously or with hormonal changes such as pregnancy or menopause.  The estimated risk for cancer is <1% in patients with noncyclic breast pain who have a normal examination and imaging results.

Extramammary pain



Most cases of extramammary pain due to chest wall pain can be managed conservatively with oral analgesics.  Breast pain due to lung, cardiac, gastrointestinal, or neurologic pathology may improve with treatment of the underlying cause.

Summary



The initial evaluation of breast pain involves a history and breast examination to determine the risk for malignancy and the most likely source of the pain.  Cyclic breast pain typically occurs in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle due to hormonal fluctuations; it is a benign condition that often self-resolves over time.  Noncyclic breast pain can occur due to various types of breast pathology and is usually evaluated with breast imaging.  Extramammary pain occurs due to pathology in surrounding tissues or organs (eg, pulmonary, cardiac, gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal, or neurologic etiologies).  Most benign causes of breast pain can be managed with reassurance and analgesics, with further intervention reserved for persistent, focal, or concerning symptoms.
